description: From Latin erasus, past participle of eradere (“to scrape, to abrade”), from ex- (“out of”) + radere (“to scrape”). Compare Middle English arasen, aracen (“to eradicate, erase”). Displaced native Old English dilegian.

examples: This subsystem is waiting to become Exclusive after having issued an erase.

verbs.description: erase (third-person singular simple present erases, present participle erasing, simple past and past participle erased)

examples: I erased that note because it was wrong.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obliterate information from (a storage medium), such as to clear or (with magnetic storage) to demagnetize.
examples: I'm going to erase this tape.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obliterate (information) from a storage medium, such as to clear or to overwrite.
examples: I'm going to erase those files.

entries.meaning: (transitive, baseball) To remove a runner from the bases via a double play or pick off play
examples: Jones was erased by a 6-4-3 double play.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be erased (have markings removed, have information removed, or be cleared of information).
(transitive) To disregard (a group, an orientation, etc.); to prevent from having an active role in society.
examples: I suggest, then, that counterdiscourses, when reductive, tend to emulate the screen discourse that erases gay sociality.
